Of the various cases, it is the oblique that exhibits the greatest differences across the Literary and Spoken registers. It has more forms in Literary Tibetan, and the way in which it functions is more complex than in the spoken language. Traditionally referred to as ལ་དོན་ “meaning of ལ་,”[1] the oblique actually subsumes three distinct markers: the markers ལ་ (and its variant ར་), དུ་ (and its variants རུ་, ཏུ་, སུ་), and finally ན་; a total of seven forms that are used as follows:

  • ལ་ is used after any ending (vowel or consonant)
  • ན་ is used after any ending (vowel or consonant)
  • ར་[2] and རུ་ are used after vowels and འ་
  • དུ་ is used after ང་, ད་, ན་, མ་, ར་, and ལ་
  • སུ་ is used after ས་
  • ཏུ་ is used after ག་, བ་, and after the ད་དྲག་

All these particles may function as the locative (without movement).

Thus any word that ends in a consonant may be followed by one of three possible particles signifying the locative.

  • བོད་དུ་ = བོད་ལ་ = བོད་ན་ “In Tibet”
  • སེམས་སུ་ = སེམས་ན་ = སེམས་ལ་ “In the mind”
  • ཤག་ཏུ་ = ཤག་ན་ = ཤག་ལ་ “In the (monastic) cell.”

When a word ends in a vowel, there is the additional possibility of using the marker ར་ instead of ལ་:

  • ལྷ་ས་རུ་ = ལྷ་ས་ན་ = ལྷ་སར་ = ལྷ་ས་ལ་ “In Lhasa”
  • ནམ་མཁའ་རུ་ = ནམ་མཁའ་ན་ = ནམ་མཁར་ = ནམ་མཁའ་ལ་ “In the sky”

However, each of the three markers has other specific functions that may be summarized briefly:

[1] There are three major problems with the way in which the ལ་དོན་ is traditionally presented in the Tibetan grammars. First, the three particles ལ་, དུ་, and ན་ are equivalent in the case of only one function (the locative without movement), but they differ in all other respects. Secondly, the grammatical analysis is based on the Sanskrit case models: accusative (ལས་སུ་བྱ་བ་), dative (དགོས་ཆེད་), and locative (གནས་གཞི་). The གནས་གཞི་ is subdivided into the possessive case (དངོས་པོའི་བདག་པོ་སྟོན་པ་), the case of object location (the locative proper) (དངོས་པོའི་གནས་གཞི་སྟོན་པ་), the case of temporal location (ཚེ་སྐབས་ལ་འཇུག་པ་), and the case of object incorporation (དེ་ཉིད་ལ་འཇུག་པ་). Finally, of the seven forms, some are actually variants of the same particle (for example སུ་, རུ་, དུ་, ཏུ་), whereas others correspond to quite different particles (for example ན་ and ལ་). In my entries to the Reference Grammar, I do not adopt the traditional presentation, since it is too complex and is based on Sanskrit syntax, which is quite unrelated to that of Tibetan.

Mention may be made of one highly unusual feature of the oblique case in Literary Tibetan: it may follow other cases, notably the agentive and the ablative, in formulations such as དེ་བས་ན་ and ནས་སུ་.

[2] In the case of a ﬁnal འ་, the latter is replaced by the case marker ར་.
